THE NEWS..LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 2.

November 8, 1909.

November 8, 1909.

WESTERN MARYLAND DEFEATED-18-6

CHEER REHEARSALS

—0—
Carroll Countians Downed by
Close Score. . An Exciting and
Valuable Game in which We
Pull Victory out of the Coals
In Second Half.

Because he finds that time is scarce
this year, "Dutch" Bryer, who has
made such a faithful and efficient
Cheer Leader, has resigned, and
"Freddie" Lee has been elected to fill
his place. Cheer practices are being
held from time to time, and all—especially the Freshmen — are urged to
come to these rehearsals. It is noticeable that the first-year men neither
know the songs or yells, nor do they
seem to take enough interest in them
to learn them properly. Notices of
the cheer practices, which are usually
held in Hopkins Hall after Laboratory, will be posted on the Gym bulle•
tin board.

THE LACROSSE CAPTAINCY
At a meeting held Friday, October
in the Trophy Room, those of the
Lacrosse Team present reluctantly
and regretfully accepted the resignation of Edmund Clary, 'ii, who feels
that he has too much other University
work to do justice to his duties as
Captain of the Lacrosse Team. Owing to the fact that so few of the
team and their substitutes could be
present it was decided not to proceed with an election to fill the place,
especially as Noble Stockett, T, who
has been acting as Captain, cannot
accept the honor. The meeting contented itself with nominating Eddie
Hulbert, 'II, and Gerhard Schmeisser, '12, for the office. The balloting
will be by mail.
The rumor has been whispered
about McCoy Hall that 'Bill' Schmeisser, '02, who for the past four years
has coached the team which each season won the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
Championship, will not be able to give
us the great advantage of his valuable
services this coming spring. It is to be
sincerely hoped that the rumor may
prove to he of the empty and unfounded variety, for we are not going to start the lacrosse work with
any too brilliant prospects, and "Big
Bill" will therefore be the more sorely missed. Graduation has cost us
the majority of last year's wonderful
team, hut "for a' that" there is no one
but hopes that the championship banner for 1910 will hang in the Trophy
Room next June.

29,

In what was probably the most sensational and exciting game ever payed by a Hopkins football team, the
strong aggregation from Western
Maryland was defeated last Saturday
week by the close score of 18 to 16.
Close as the score looks on paper, it
does not even begin to show how
thrilling was the game, or how it sent

BOARD MEETING
—0—
Advisors Appointed for Lacrosse
and Track Teams—Two AsManagers
Football
sistant
Elected — St. John's Game at

ATHLETIC

Homewood.
The Athletic Association Board
held a meeting last Monday afternoon in the Trophy Room, and Bill
Schmeisser, '02, and Alan Diel, '04,
who last year coached the Navy Lacrosse Team, were appointed the advisers to the Lacrosse Team for this
coming season. The Track Team also
had its advisers elected, and Curzon
Hoffman, 'or, who coached the team
last year, and Joe England, "02, are
to serve in this capacity.
It was also decided to have two
Assistant Managers appointed for the
Football Team from the Sophomore
class, though Seymour Merrick, 'T
will in all probabilty continue to fill
the responsible position he now holds.
;it the future the Managers of all
teams are to be Seniors, with a Junior Assistant Manager and two Associate Managers selected from among
the Sophomores. The Sophomores appointed this year are Williams Haynes
and James E. L. Holmes.
The St. Johns game is definitely
decided for Homewood this year, and
it was also voted to give a season
ticket to the Varsity cheer leader.
It was the unanimous opinion
of the meeting that, now we have
four classes, the Captains and Managers of the Varsity Teams be only
selected from the Senior Class, and
the future actions of the Board are
to be governed by this sentiment, and
it is hoped that the teams at their
elections will follow this excellent
precedent.

(-whined from Column T.
'or, but the team from Carroll county
was not beaten, for getting the ball
in mid-field they rushed it down by
means of cleverly executed forward
passes, and pushed it over with a mass
play off tackle. There was six minutes' play and it certainly looked dubious whether or not we could score
again, but the team responded nobly
to the call and literally pulled the game
out of the coals for the second time.
The game was most valuable, and
the less -is learned from it by the
coaches will probably put an end to
the shifting about that the team has
The game showed
been having.
where the weaker points lay in the
line, which up till then had not been
able to be pierced. It also taught
some valuable lessons in the hack
field and on the ends. To pick out
the stars would he difficult, but Ried,
McCabe, Michael, Mills, Bridgeman
AND Stollenwerck were certainly
factors in the victory.

ST. JOHN'S GAME OFFICIALS
At a recent meeting between the
representatives of the two teams the
officials were selected for the game
with St. John's. "Archie" Hunter, of
the Maryland Athletic Club, who has
acted as an official at so many football and lacrosse games at Homewood,
is to bt the referee. "Joe" Gilman,
of Dartmouth,has been selected as the
umpire, while the bead linesman will
be "Hank" Shaw, of Princeton.
Prof.—Will someone please tell me
what is meant by a "perennial smile"?
Giddy Soph.—It is one which reaches from (y)ear to (y)ear.

THE NEWS-LETTER
COTILLION CLUB

The Board•of Governors of the Cotillon Club, consisting of Edmund B.
Clary (chairman), E. Carroll Stollenwerck(secretary and treasurer), A. C.
Woods, E. D. Martin, F. C. Lee and
G. H. Hayne, has announced DecentLer to, February 4, and April 29 at
the dates for the cotillions. All of
the above dates are Fridays, and it is
to be hoped that even the studious y
inclined will honor the ladies with
their presence.
The dances will, as usual, start at
8.30 and end at midnight. The pr t gramme generally consists of sixteen
dances, with a light :iinpper between
the eighth and ninth dances. In the
past the Cotillion Board has secured
the services of Emerich's Orchestra,
which is concealed behind a bank of
palms on the platform. When McCoy Hall is decorated with flags of
former classes and athletic trophies it
indeed presents a contrast to the McCoy Hall of every day.
The wives of the members of the
Faculty serve as chaperones and lend
beauty as well as dignity to the festive occasions.

THE NEWS..LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 2.

November 8, 1909.

November 8, 1909.

WESTERN MARYLAND DEFEATED-18-6

CHEER REHEARSALS

—0—
Carroll Countians Downed by
Close Score. . An Exciting and
Valuable Game in which We
Pull Victory out of the Coals
In Second Half.

Because he finds that time is scarce
this year, "Dutch" Bryer, who has
made such a faithful and efficient
Cheer Leader, has resigned, and
"Freddie" Lee has been elected to fill
his place. Cheer practices are being
held from time to time, and all—especially the Freshmen — are urged to
come to these rehearsals. It is noticeable that the first-year men neither
know the songs or yells, nor do they
seem to take enough interest in them
to learn them properly. Notices of
the cheer practices, which are usually
held in Hopkins Hall after Laboratory, will be posted on the Gym bulle•
tin board.

THE LACROSSE CAPTAINCY
At a meeting held Friday, October
in the Trophy Room, those of the
Lacrosse Team present reluctantly
and regretfully accepted the resignation of Edmund Clary, 'ii, who feels
that he has too much other University
work to do justice to his duties as
Captain of the Lacrosse Team. Owing to the fact that so few of the
team and their substitutes could be
present it was decided not to proceed with an election to fill the place,
especially as Noble Stockett, T, who
has been acting as Captain, cannot
accept the honor. The meeting contented itself with nominating Eddie
Hulbert, 'II, and Gerhard Schmeisser, '12, for the office. The balloting
will be by mail.
The rumor has been whispered
about McCoy Hall that 'Bill' Schmeisser, '02, who for the past four years
has coached the team which each season won the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
Championship, will not be able to give
us the great advantage of his valuable
services this coming spring. It is to be
sincerely hoped that the rumor may
prove to he of the empty and unfounded variety, for we are not going to start the lacrosse work with
any too brilliant prospects, and "Big
Bill" will therefore be the more sorely missed. Graduation has cost us
the majority of last year's wonderful
team, hut "for a' that" there is no one
but hopes that the championship banner for 1910 will hang in the Trophy
Room next June.

29,

week by the close score of 18 to 16.

BOARD MEETING
—0—
Advisors Appointed for Lacrosse
and Track Teams—Two AsManagers
Football
sistant
Elected — St. John's Game at

ATHLETIC

Homewood.
The Athletic Association Board
held a meeting last Monday afternoon in the Trophy Room, and Bill
Schmeisser, '02, and Alan Diel, '04,
who last year coached the Navy Lacrosse Team, were appointed the advisers to the Lacrosse Team for this
coming season. The Track Team also
had its advisers elected, and Curzon
Hoffman, 'or, who coached the team
last year, and Joe England, "02, are
to serve in this capacity.
It was also decided to have two
Assistant Managers appointed for the
Football Team from the Sophomore
class, though Seymour Merrick, 'T
will in all probabilty continue to fill
the responsible position he now holds.
;it the future the Managers of all
teams are to be Seniors, with a Junior Assistant Manager and two Associate Managers selected from among
the Sophomores. The Sophomores appointed this year are Williams Haynes
and James E. L. Holmes.
The St. Johns game is definitely
decided for Homewood this year, and
it was also voted to give a season
ticket to the Varsity cheer leader.
It was the unanimous opinion
of the meeting that, now we have
four classes, the Captains and Managers of the Varsity Teams be only
selected from the Senior Class, and
the future actions of the Board are
to be governed by this sentiment, and
it is hoped that the teams at their
elections will follow this excellent
precedent.

(-whined from Column T.
'or, but the team from Carroll county
was not beaten, for getting the ball
in mid-field they rushed it down by
means of cleverly executed forward
passes, and pushed it over with a mass
play off tackle. There was six minutes' play and it certainly looked dubious whether or not we could score
again, but the team responded nobly
to the call and literally pulled the game
out of the coals for the second time.
The game was most valuable, and
the less -is learned from it by the
coaches will probably put an end to
the shifting about that the team has
The game showed
been having.
where the weaker points lay in the
line, which up till then had not been
able to be pierced. It also taught
some valuable lessons in the hack
field and on the ends. To pick out
the stars would he difficult, but Ried,
McCabe, Michael, Mills, Bridgeman
AND Stollenwerck were certainly
factors in the victory.

ST. JOHN'S GAME OFFICIALS
At a recent meeting between the
representatives of the two teams the
officials were selected for the game
with St. John's. "Archie" Hunter, of
the Maryland Athletic Club, who has
acted as an official at so many football and lacrosse games at Homewood,
is to bt the referee. "Joe" Gilman,
of Dartmouth,has been selected as the
umpire, while the bead linesman will
be "Hank" Shaw, of Princeton.
Prof.—Will someone please tell me
what is meant by a "perennial smile"?
Giddy Soph.—It is one which reaches from (y)ear to (y)ear.

THE NEWS-LETTER
COTILLION CLUB

The Board•of Governors of the Cotillon Club, consisting of Edmund B.
Clary (chairman), E. Carroll Stollenwerck(secretary and treasurer), A. C.
Woods, E. D. Martin, F. C. Lee and
G. H. Hayne, has announced DecentLer to, February 4, and April 29 at
the dates for the cotillions. All of
the above dates are Fridays, and it is
to be hoped that even the studious y
inclined will honor the ladies with
their presence.
The dances will, as usual, start at
8.30 and end at midnight. The pr t gramme generally consists of sixteen
dances, with a light :iinpper between
the eighth and ninth dances. In the
past the Cotillion Board has secured
the services of Emerich's Orchestra,
which is concealed behind a bank of
palms on the platform. When McCoy Hall is decorated with flags of
former classes and athletic trophies it
indeed presents a contrast to the McCoy Hall of every day.
The wives of the members of the
Faculty serve as chaperones and lend
beauty as well as dignity to the festive occasions.
